description: AI literacy defines the abiliteis of individuals to understand, interact with, and critically evaluate artificial intelligence techniques and systems. We quantify and improve people's AI literacy to enhance trust, accountability, and  decision-making.

We study how users perceive and maintain trust in computational models like probabilistic forecasts and machine learning tehcniques, especially in the domains of healthcare and policy-making. Our visual methods enhance the interpretability of model and  enable users to make appropriate decisions.

We explore how to convey the inherent uncertainties in model predictions to the public. Our work focuses on developing visual methods for journalists to present probabilistic electoral forecasts. Additionally, we investigate the impact of such reporting on voter behavior and trust in the electoral process.

We also work on understanding how people perceive, interpret, and interact with visual representations of data. We evaluate the usability and impact of different visualization designs through empirical studies and user feedback.

Visualization literacy is an essential skill for accurately interpreting data to inform critical decisions.  We study the following questions: How can we measure more aspects of visualization literacy? How can we efficiently measure visualization literacy? How can we generate diverse visualization literacy test items at scale?
We explore the use of immersive technologies, such as virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR), to enhance data analysis and understanding.
